chatbot.title: Financial Assistant
chatbot.welcome: Hello! I'm your financial assistant. I can answer questions about savings, investments, and debt management. How can I help you?
chatbot.error: Sorry, an error occurred. Please try again.

debtVsInvestment.question: I have debt, should I invest?
debtVsInvestment.answer: No, I recommend paying off your debts first. Because debt interest rates (typically 15-30%) are much higher than investment returns (8-12%). By paying off high-interest debts first, you can achieve a 'guaranteed return'. Then start investing.

emergencyFund.question: How much should my emergency fund be?
emergencyFund.answer: Your emergency fund should cover 3-6 months of expenses. For example, if your monthly expenses are $1,000, you should have $3,000-6,000 in emergency savings. Keep this money in an easily accessible account (savings account or money market fund).

savingsRate.question: How much should I save?
savingsRate.answer: You should save at least 20% of your income. If you're aiming for early retirement (FIRE), you may need to save 50% or more. Start small: Save 10% first, then increase by 5% annually.

fireBasics.question: What is FIRE, how do I start?
fireBasics.answer: FIRE (Financial Independence, Retire Early) is the early retirement movement. Basic rule: Save 25 times your annual expenses. For example, if you spend $40,000 per year, you need to save $1,000,000. If you invest this at 4% return, you'll earn $40,000 per year.

investmentStart.question: How should I make my first investment?
investmentStart.answer: 1) First, build an emergency fund (3-6 months of expenses). 2) Pay off high-interest debts. 3) Then start investing: You can begin with index funds or stock funds. Start with small amounts, invest regularly monthly.

debtPayoff.question: How should I pay off my debts?
debtPayoff.answer: There are 2 strategies: 1) Snowball: Pay off your smallest debt first, provides motivation. 2) Avalanche: Pay off the highest interest debt first, saves more money. I recommend the Avalanche method because it's more logical.

privacyPolicy.title: Privacy Policy

dataCollection.title: Data Collection
dataCollection.content: Payment Tracker app does not collect any personal data. All your payment and income information is stored locally on your device and is not sent to any server.

dataStorage.title: Data Storage
dataStorage.content:
• All data is stored in your device's local storage (AsyncStorage)
• Your data is only accessible to you
• All data is automatically deleted when the app is uninstalled
• You can export your data using the backup feature

dataSharing.title: Third-Party Sharing
dataSharing.content: Payment Tracker app does not share any data with third parties. Your data stays only on your device and is not sent anywhere over the internet.

notifications.title: Notifications
notifications.content: The app uses local notifications for payment reminders. These notifications are generated only on your device and do not send any information to any server. You can disable notifications at any time from settings.

permissions.title: App Permissions
permissions.content:
Payment Tracker app uses the following permissions:

• Notifications: To send payment reminders
• Storage: To save backup files

security.title: Data Security
security.content: Your data is securely stored in your device's local storage. We recommend using a screen lock and password to ensure your device's security.

children.title: Children's Privacy
children.content: Our app does not knowingly collect data from children under 13 years of age. Parents should supervise their children's use of the app.

changes.title: Policy Changes
changes.content: This privacy policy may be updated from time to time. You will be notified within the app when significant changes occur.

contact.title: Contact
contact.content:
If you have any questions about our privacy policy, please contact us:

Email: destek@odemetakibi.com

privacyPolicy.footer: By using the Payment Tracker app, you agree to this privacy policy.
